message_1:
In propositional logic, show that the following is a tautology: 

(p ∧ ¬q) → (¬q ∨ ¬p)
message_2:
To show that (p ∧ ¬q) → (¬q ∨ ¬p) is a tautology, we can use a truth table. A tautology is a statement that is always true, regardless of the truth values of its variables. In this case, we have two variables, p and q. We will consider all possible combinations of truth values for p and q, and then evaluate the given expression.

Here is the truth table for (p ∧ ¬q) → (¬q ∨ ¬p):

| p | q | ¬q | p ∧ ¬q | ¬p | ¬q ∨ ¬p | (p ∧ ¬q) → (¬q ∨ ¬p) |
|---|---|----|-------|----|--------|---------------------|
| T | T |  F |   F   |  F |   F    |          T          |
| T | F |  T |   T   |  F |   T    |          T          |
| F | T |  F |   F   |  T |   T    |          T          |
| F | F |  T |   F   |  T |   T    |          T          |

In the table, T represents True and F represents False. We can see that the given expression (p ∧ ¬q) → (¬q ∨ ¬p) is true for all possible combinations of truth values for p and q. Therefore, it is a tautology.
